description.narrative: This project is a low emission capacity building project focuses on strengthening Uganda’s technical and institutional capacity in the development of Green House Gas inventory systems and Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

Target 1:Integrated governance to deliver on NDC outcomes achieved
Target 2: Capacities developed to design climate friendly investments, address investor risk, blend and catalyze climate finance
Target 3: Evidence-based design and planning of mitigation actions delivered
Target 4: Strengthened platform for evidence-based learning, advocacy and exchange of knowledge and experiences

Target 1:Integrated governance to deliver on NDC outcomes achieved Results; 1.In collaboration with the Ministry of Water and Environment’s Climate Change Department, an integrated Monitoring Reporting and Verification (MRV) tool has been developed to enhance data collection, tracking and reporting on climate actions including the NDC actions. The integrated MRV tool and database builds on the national MRV framework that has been developed and will assist in estimating the annual national GHG emissions and inventory from the GHG emission sectors, enhance tracking and monitoring the climate actions on mitigation and adaptation, policies, programmes and most importantly climate finance flows and relevant Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) impacts. he tool provides an overarching framework for: oGHG emission monitoring. oInternational and domestic reporting requirements (e.g. National Communications (NCs), Biannual Technical Reports (BTR) etc); oReal-time monitoring of GHG mitigation and adaptation actions; oFinancial flows and financial support received and progress towards implementation of climate actions; oQuantifying Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) impacts of mitigation and adaptation actions and monitoring and progress on achieving the SDGs. 2.Capacity building has been conducted on the integrated MRV tool for staff in the Ministry of Water and Environment’s Climate Change Department and MRV focal points in different institutions. This was 3 days training on the use of the integrated MRV tool was conducted for 18 (10M;8F) staff from the Ministry of Water and Environment’s Climate Change Department and 40 (25 M; 15F) MRV focal points from the different institutions who included representatives from government agencies, private sector, and Civil Society organizations. This enhanced their capacity to use the tool for data collection and reporting purposes. 3.A user operations manual was developed and used during the training on the integrated MRV tool. The user manual will be utilised by the Ministry of Water and Environment’s Climate Change Development and the MRV focal points in the utilization of the tool. 4.The capacity of Ugandan negotiators was enhanced through participation in the 26th Conference of Parties (COP 26) conference. In collaboration with the Ministry of Water and Environment, the programme organized the national Preparatory conference on COP26 (Pre COP26). The conference was attended by 85 (56M; 29F) participants who included representatives from government, youth, and Civil Society Organization- many of whom were negotiators or observers during the negotiation process. The national COP26 position paper was presented and discussed during this workshop. The conference equipped negotiators with adequate knowledge and skills to strongly participate in COP26. During the conference, the youth COP26 position paper was presented by the youth for discussion. The conference was broadcast on National Television called NTV and the proceedings for the event can be found via this link.
Target 2: Capacities developed to design climate friendly investments, address investor risk, blend and catalyze climate finance Results; 1.Six women and youth led organizations supported with climate action grants; Six organizations that are implementing projects contributing towards the implementation of Uganda’s NDC have been supported with climate action grants. These organizations include Ngenge Development Foundation (NDF), Centre for Climate and Ecosystems for Social Initiatives (CLESI), Bubukanza Youth Farmers Group, Kangai Integrated Community Development Initiative (KICDI), Living Earth Uganda (LEU) and Kataara Womens Poverty Alleviation group. These organizations are implementing a wide range of technologies and practices contributing to climate change mitigation and adaptation. These technologies and services include energy efficient cook stoves, climate smart agricultural practices, tree planting, solar PV for households and energy efficient cooking technologies including briquettes. The organizations were supported with small grants ranging between US$ 8,000 and US$ 10,000 to implement activities and measures that contribute to Uganda’s NDC in key sectors including energy, forestry, agriculture, waste management
2.A concept on the climate finance facility for Uganda has been developed and a phased approach was prepared regarding the design of the facility. Three phases are proposed in the structure of the facility. Phase 1 involves Case Building and Structure Options including a market analysis, capitalization options, and stakeholder outreach. Phase 2 includes Project Preparation Facility Design, Capitalization & Operationalization and Phase 3 includes the design of the credit facility, capitalization and operationalization options. The finance facility will assist to mobile resources from public and private sources for climate action and enhance engagement of the private sector in climate action. The facility will enhance coordination among development partners and financing institutions to consolidate the mobilization of means of implementation (i.e., finance, capacity building, technology transfer) from both national and international sources, including the private sector.
Target 3: Evidence-based design and planning of mitigation actions delivered Results; 1.Implementation and resource mobilization plan of the updated NDC; Support has been provided to develop Uganda’s updated NDC implementation and resource mobilization plan and 5 concepts of the NDC priority areas for financing. An inception report with a defined approach and plan for the development of Uganda’s updated NDC implementation plan was prepared and a workshop was held to discuss the scope of the implementation plan, resource mobilization plan and concept notes that will be developed with new funding into fully fledged proposals for the key NDC priority sectors and areas. Stakeholder consultations about the draft NDC implementation plan are ongoing and the plan is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2022.
Target 4: Strengthened platform for evidence-based learning, advocacy and exchange of knowledge and experiences Results; 1.Africa Climate week organized and hosted by Uganda; In collaboration with the Ministry of Water and Environment’s Climate Change Department, technical support was provided to organize Africa Climate week (ACW) that took place 26-29 September 2021. The ACW was hosted virtually by Uganda and was supported by UNFCCC, World Bank Group, UNDP, UNEP and Africa Development Bank. The event enhanced collaboration between all actors ranging from the government, private sector, youth, Civil Society organizations (CSOs) towards equitable, inclusive, locally led climate resilience for and accelerated collaboration and integrated climate action into recovery from the global pandemic. The event showcased action that demonstrated momentum building for COP 26, enabled the tracking of progress on submission of stronger NDCs, provided information on the Race-To-Zero and Race-To-Resilience campaigns by UNFCCC that mobilize actors outside national governments including businesses, cities, regions and investors to join the climate ambition alliance and contribute towards a healthy, resilient and zero carbon recovery information and offered stakeholders a platform to have their voices heard in the UN Climate Change process. The report with the outputs of the climate week can be found via this link. 2.Technical support provided to organize track 2 of the Africa Climate week that focused on Integrated approaches to climate resilience development. This session was organized in collaboration with UNFCCC and several partners who included development partners, Civil Society organizations, youth organizations such as UNCDF, Africa Development Bank, UNEP, World Bank, Africa Youth Initiative on Climate Change organized sessions which enhanced the knowledge of participants on the alignment of NDCs with National Adaptation Plans (NAPs), emphasized the need to support the design of gender-sensitive implementation strategies in NAPs, emphasized the need for strengthened data and information systems are necessary for formulation of evidence-based policies and plans and the role of partnerships across sectors and to build political will, increase policy coherence and facilitate financing flows. 3.An article about the ACW was published and can be found via this link https://www.ug.undp.org/content/uganda/en/home/presscenter/articles/2021/leaders-pledge-climate-action-support-as-uganda-hosts-2021-afric.html In addition, the Africa climate week was aired on the National TV with the aim to create awareness amongst the public on the Uganda’s efforts on climate action and can be accessed via this link. 4.Workshop organised on strengthening multi-level and inclusive governance for NDC implementation. The session enhanced sharing of country experiences, to help countries achieve their NDC targets and join efforts, and discussed challenges and best practices for NDC implementation, with a focus on capacity-building, technology transfer, lasting inclusivity, and societal ownership. 5.Awareness materials have been developed to increase knowledge and understanding of stakeholders regarding the country’s NDC and the NDC priority sectors and mitigation and adaptation actions in the revised NDC for Uganda. These awareness materials include the summary of the updated NDC for policy makers, a brief NDC booklet with key priority adaptation and mitigation actions, a report on circular economy opportunities for Uganda and a report on enhanced mitigation and adaptation targets.
Target 5: Uganda’s NDC enhanced Results;
1.Uganda’s updated NDC finalized; The NDC Support Programme has supported the Government of Uganda through the Ministry of Water and Environment Climate Change Department to update Uganda’s Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) to the Paris Agreement. This support has been provided under the Climate Promise initiative. Key achievements supported include a. The revision of the NDC through a high multi stakeholder and inclusive process. The revised NDC has been finalized and is awaiting approval by the National Climate Change Advisory Committee; b. Update of the standardized baseline on improved institutional cookstoves has been conducted- the standardized baseline will facilitate the calculation of emission reductions in the biomass sector and enhance participation in article 6 mechanisms; c. Development of emission factors for the waste sector has been undertaken to facilitate the development of carbon finance projects in the waste sector; (iv) The NDC has been aligned to the LTS through partnership with the German Development Cooperation (GIZ) which support ed the development of the LTS. d.Partnerships have been created with several development partners through the NDC enhancement process and these partners include GIZ, International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) which jointly worked with UNDP to facilitate the sector validation workshops. The NDC revision process has also been well aligned with key policy documents including the third National development Plan, Climate change policy, Green Growth Development strategy among others. Uganda has increased its ambition on mitigation and adaptation by including new sectors in the updated NDC. The adaptation targets and mitigation targets have been enhanced in key sectors including Agriculture, Forestry and Landuse (AFOLU), energy, transport, waste and Industrial Processes and Product Use (IPPU) sectors and Uganda has committed to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions reduced by 24.7% below the BAU trajectory by 2030. 2. A multi stakeholder consultation process was supported to gain input from stakeholders on the draft NDC document. This involved stakeholder consultation with representatives from the district local governments, ministries, departments and agencies, youth, Civil Society Organizations, and the private sector. These consultations included a.5 regional stakeholder consultations conducted in the district local governments across 5 regions of the Country including central region, Eastern region, Northern Uganda, West Nile and Western region with representatives from the district local governments, private sector, youth, and Civil Society Organizations, b.4 sectoral national consultations conducted at national level. These c.A National validation workshop of Uganda’s NDC to discuss the final draft of the updated NDC. This event was aired on National television called NTV Uganda to ensure awareness of Uganda’s NDC to the entire population and can be accessed via this link. In total, 425 people (284M; 141F) were engaged in all the stakeholder consultations. A stakeholder consultation report with the key outcomes of the consultations can be found here. 3.A Circular Economy assessment was conducted to assess and understand the stocks and flows of resources and assets and identify GHG emission hotspots and priority areas where circular economy activities could enhance Uganda’s NDC. 4.In addition, a report on enhanced mitigation and adaptation targets was prepared that summarized feedback from the NDC stakeholder consultations on both adaptation and mitigation, details on the approach and methodology for mitigation and adaptation to derive the emission scenarios and targets.
